ygData.subject: Re: Open science software/experiment repository
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all, I d just like to add that I really like the proposition, but for experiments other than just demos it s probably not a good idea. We will also run into

Hi all, 

I'd just like to add that I really like the proposition, but for =
experiments other than just demos it's probably not a good idea. We will al=
so run into software compatibility issues right away when such a thing gets=
 started. And there are domains in which the software is almost useless, li=
ke in robotics when you test stuff on hardware that probably nobody else ha=
s or it is used in specific environments. 

I think a better idea is to hav=
e a common software infrastructure for simulations. Much like standard benc=
hmarks, a piece of software that brings results we can all agree upon. 

Pe=
ter


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken Lloyd"  wrote:
>
> Ken Stanley,
> 
=
>  
> 
> Excellent point.  The aspects of a) validating existing experiment=
al data,
> and 2) extending experimentation on priors into new realms, is m=
essy,
> humbling business.  Often, it is akin to exposing your dirty laundr=
y to
> others.  For most of us, it merely shows us how much we don't know, =
and the
> need further work to find out.
> 
>  
> 
> Eventually, if we have=
 something meaningful to contribute, hopefully we will
> publish it so othe=
rs can further the cause.  The problem with application of
> an approach in=
 new domains is:  You find yourself having to explain all the
> inferential=
 steps, what they mean and how they work (Yudkowsky - Expecting
> Short Inf=
erential Distances).  Strangely enough, you might be able to encode
> a hom=
ology of chain complexes in something like a hyper-dimensional, CPPN to
> d=
o just that .
> 
>  
> 
> Ken Lloyd
> 
>  
> 
> From: neat@yahoogroups.com =
[mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Ken
> Sent: Friday, January 18, =
2013 1:21 AM
> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [neat] Re: Open science =
software/experiment repository
> 
>  
> 
>   
> 
> 
> 
> I'm all for releas=
ing code and our group tries to do that with our own
> research, but I woul=
d be hesitant about the idea of using scholarly
> organizations to require =
people to do it. Like many well-intended rules, I
> can imagine a lot of na=
sty unintended consequences. At a cultural level, it
> would further enshri=
ne the current benchmark obsession in machine learning
> at the expense of =
focusing on ideas. More practically, it will mean that
> reviewers will sta=
rt rejecting papers based on supposed code glitches in
> required code subm=
issions. That will give reviewers a whole new
> justification for completel=
y ignoring the main of idea of the paper. 
> 
> Students will also become o=
verwhelmed with code emergencies (since
> publication will depend now upon =
strangers running your code) and code
> cleanups demanded by random strange=
rs who may themselves be at fault or
> simply ignorant. Furthermore, in a f=
ew years we will have massive
> repositories of junk code (think of the hun=
dreds of papers published only at
> GECCO in one year) that is so out of da=
te that it requires deprecated
> compilers and computing platforms even to =
run. But we will be required to
> maintain these repositories, which will b=
ecome increasingly ignored, simply
> to maintain the appearance of rigor.
>=
 
> I'd prefer just to leave it voluntary and concentrate on making it easi=
er to
> find code from people who actually want to share it and keep it up =
to date. 
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com  , Oliver Coleman
> =
wrote:
> >
> > Yes, you make a lot of good points. It would almost certainl=
y need support
> > from a publisher, or other institutions like funding bod=
ies or
> universities
> > to go anywhere.
> > 
> > Has anyone you know of l=
ooked into getting such organisations to require
> > submitting their data =
and code to an open repository? I'm probably getting
> > ahead of myself he=
re, I don't know enough about the publishers and other
> > organisations (e=
xcept perhaps my own university) to know where to start on
> > such a thing=
... :)
> > 
> > That's a pity about Dryad only accepting CC licenses, I was=
 planning on
> > using it for my next paper but my code is GPL.
> > 
> > 
>=
 > 
> > 
> > On 17 January 2013 23:32, wrote:
> > 
> > > **
> > >
> > >
> >=
 > Hi-
> > >
> > >
> > > > For those also interested in this, the previous =
link didn't work, it
> > > looks
> > > > like it has an extra x at the end =
and should have been:
> > > > http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evorob_db/moin.wsgi=

> > >
> > > Oops, sorry for this. I don't know where the x is coming from.=

> > >
> > >
> > > >
> > > > Perhaps it would be good to create such a site=
 (either as wiki or a
> more
> > > > structured set-up) for artificial evol=
ution research in general (with
> > > > tags/categories for sub-fields).
> =
> >
> > > The main issue with a general website is that it will never be th=
e main
> > > reference. In my opinion, having a website with many sub-field=
s means
> that
> > > most people in these sub-fields will not be aware of t=
he website, that
> > > they will use their own solutions and, overall, that=
 the site will be
> > > mostly empty. As a consequence, people will not thi=
nk about this website
> > > as _the_ place to check and to submit. Put diff=
erently, I think that
> such
> > > a general website has a high probability=
 of being a "ghost website"
> > > without enough inhabitants to survive. It=
's "easy" to program a website,
> > > it's much harder to make it alive and=
 successful.
> > >
> > > That's why we tried to do something for our own, s=
mall sub-field: our
> goal
> > > is to be one of the reference pages (and e=
ven this is hard!).
> > >
> > > The only way I can envision a successful ge=
neral website is if it is
> > > mandatory to publish a paper. For instance,=
 GECCO could require the
> > > submision on a specific website of the sourc=
e code of every accepted
> > > paper.
> > >
> > > By the way, many journals=
 in biology now require that the authors of
> > > accepted papers put their=
 data (and potentially their source code) on
> the
> > > Dryad repository (=
http://datadryad.org/). I hope the evolutionary
> > > computation field wil=
l be able to do the same!
> > >
> > > [Dryad could be used by the EC commun=
ity but it does not accept
> > > GPL-licensed source code -- only creative =
commons --, whereas I think
> that
> > > many EC frameworks are distributed=
 with a GPL-like license]
> > >
> > > Best regards,
> > > -- JBM
> > > http=
://people.isir.upmc.fr/mouret/
> > >
> > > 
> > >
